name: Yimenosaurus
overview: Yimenosaurus is an extinct genus of plateosaurid sauropodomorph dinosaur that lived in China in the Early Jurassic. The genus was first named in 1990 by Ziqi Bai, Jie Yang and Guohui Wang, along with its type and only species, Yimenosaurus youngi. The species name honours renowned Chinese paleontologist Yang Zhongjian, the father of Chinese paleontology, known as C.C. Young in English. Known material includes the holotype, an almost complete skull and mandible, as well as incomplete cervical and dorsal vertebrae, a mostly complete sacrum, an ilium, ischia, partial ribs and complete femur, and a paratype, a well-preserved postcrania with a fragmentary skull. In 2010 Paul estimated its length at 9 metres (30 ft) and its weight at 2 tonnes.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Yimenosaurus is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.

funFacts: Yimenosaurus remains an active target for revision as new material is compared across related taxa.
Dino-pedia marks uncertain claims explicitly so this article can be upgraded with specimen-level evidence.
